newsitem.title: FRANCE: Fire hits Paris law courts near historic church.
newsitem.headline: Fire hits Paris law courts near historic church.

text.p: A fire broke out on Tuesday in the Paris law courts, threatening the historic Sainte Chapelle, a 13th century church which stands in a courtyard of the courts building, guards said.
The fire broke out in a part of the building's basement in an area used to store court documents, they said.
The cause was not immediately known.
Smoke billowed over the area and the courtyard where the Sainte Chapelle stands was ordered evacuated by police, they said.
The law courts are located on the Cite island in the centre of the River Seine in the heart of the French capital.

The Sainte Chapelle, a Gothic architectural masterpiece and major Paris tourist attraction, was built by the French king Saint Louis in 1245 to house relics he gathered during the Crusades. Construction took three years.
The church's upper chapel has towering stained glass windows which were removed from the church in pieces and hidden during the Nazi occupation years in World War Two.
